study.title: Tai Chi Mind-Body Therapy for Knee Osteoarthritis
study.brief_description: The purpose of this study was to compare the safety and effectiveness of Tai Chi with an Attention Control intervention consisting of a stretching and wellness education program involving 40 patients with osteoarthritis (OA) of the knee. We hypothesized that the participants receiving Tai Chi would show greater improvement in knee pain, physical and psychological functioning, and health-related quality of life than participants in the Attention Control group, and that the benefit would be mediated by effects on muscle function, musculoskeletal flexibility and mental health.

front_details.question: Did practicing Tai Chi improve knee pain (WOMAC pain score) in people with knee osteoarthritis compared to wellness education and stretching after 12 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: practicing Tai Chi
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: people with knee osteoarthritis
front_details.outcome_fragment: knee pain (WOMAC pain score)

study.title: VR Intervention to Improve Police Safety
study.brief_description: The primary objective of this study is to demonstrate the efficacy of Floreo's police safety module (PSM) in adolescents and adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) by assessing improvement in police interaction skills as compared to a video modeling intervention.

front_details.question: Did remote at-home immersive VR police-safety training improve police interaction skills (change in Police Interaction Assessment score) in adolescents and adults with autism (ASD) compared to treatment-as-usual (no intervention) after ~2 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: remote at-home immersive VR police-safety training
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adolescents and adults with autism (ASD)
front_details.outcome_fragment: police interaction skills (change in Police Interaction Assessment score)

study.title: Combination Treatment for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) After the World Trade Center (WTC) Attack
study.brief_description: This randomized controlled trial evaluates efficacy of combined prolonged exposure (PE) and the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) paroxetine in the treatment of survivors of the World Trade Center (WTC) attacks.

front_details.question: Did paroxetine (an SSRI) plus prolonged exposure therapy improve PTSD severity (Clinician-Administered PTSD Scale, CAPS) in survivors of the World Trade Center attacks compared to placebo pill plus prolonged exposure therapy after 10 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: paroxetine (an SSRI) plus prolonged exposure therapy
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: survivors of the World Trade Center attacks
front_details.outcome_fragment: PTSD severity (Clinician-Administered PTSD Scale, CAPS)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: placebo pill plus prolonged exposure therapy

study.title: Improved Outcome in Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant (HSCT) Patients by Reducing Caregiver Distress
study.brief_description: PURPOSE: As this is a randomized controlled trial, all subjects receiving stress management psychoeducation will be expected to obtain a new set of coping skills that will allow them to better deal with the stressors of caregiving for an allogeneic HSCT patient. It is expected that improving caregiver status will improve patient quality of life.

front_details.question: Did caregiver psychoeducation and relaxation (fPER) via phone/video improve caregiver distress (composite of depression, anxiety, and stress) in caregivers of allogeneic HSCT patients compared to treatment as usual (TAU) after 6 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: caregiver psychoeducation and relaxation (fPER) via phone/video
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: caregivers of allogeneic HSCT patients
front_details.outcome_fragment: caregiver distress (composite of depression, anxiety, and stress)

study.title: VR Intervention to Improve Police Safety
study.brief_description: The primary objective of this study is to demonstrate the efficacy of Floreo's police safety module (PSM) in adolescents and adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) by assessing improvement in police interaction skills as compared to a video modeling intervention.

front_details.question: Did immersive VR police-safety training (Floreo PSM) improve police interaction skills (Police Interaction Assessment score) in adolescents and adults with ASD compared to video-based training (BE SAFE) after 2 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: immersive VR police-safety training (Floreo PSM)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adolescents and adults with ASD
front_details.outcome_fragment: police interaction skills (Police Interaction Assessment score)

study.title: A Mobile, Semi-automated Text Message-based Intervention to Prevent Perceived Low or Insufficient Milk Supply
study.brief_description:
The purpose of this pilot randomized trial is to determine the effectiveness, feasibility, and acceptability of a mobile, semi-automated text message-based intervention (MILK) to prevent perceived low or insufficient milk supply (PIM) among mothers without prior breastfeeding experience. PIM is the leading cause of premature breastfeeding cessation, and prior work shows that it is often rooted in low breastfeeding self-efficacy and misconceptions about lactation physiology and trajectory. The MILK intervention is designed to address PIM, as well as other common breastfeeding problems via semi-automated text messages of prenatal and postpartum breastfeeding education and support. Messages are time-sensitive (e.g., specific to gestational age, time since delivery) and based on the Breastfeeding Self-Efficacy (Social Cognitive) Theory; they are also modeled from pilot work that investigated how first-time mothers view, manage and describe breastfeeding problems. Messages were vetted with clinical lactation experts, as well as pregnant and postpartum women with no other children.

The MILK intervention will be trialed against a control intervention group, who will receive general perinatal education through the national Text4Baby system. The investigators will recruit approximately 186 healthy, pregnant women at 13-25 weeks gestation from Magee Women's Hospital clinics and outpatient sites. Women will be randomized via computer-generated simple randomization to the experimental or control intervention. Both groups will receive text messages 3-5 times per week from week 25 of pregnancy through week 8 postpartum. Measured outcomes of interest will include perceived breast milk supply, breastfeeding confidence, maternal anxiety, breastfeeding exclusivity, and breastfeeding duration. Data will be collected at baseline (13-25 gestational weeks), 34-36 gestational weeks, and at 1, 2, 4, and 8 weeks postpartum via online survey or telephone call. To assess the potential longer-term impact of the intervention, breastfeeding continuation and exclusivity will be reassessed via telephone at 6 months postpartum. Between group and group x time differences in outcome measures will be examined graphically and via linear mixed modeling. To inform modifications to MILK, telephone interviews will be conducted with a subset of participants in each group to assess and compare intervention use, burdens and challenges, and suggested alterations (8 weeks).

front_details.question: Did semi-automated breastfeeding support text messages (MILK) improve perceived milk supply (feeling you have enough breast milk) in first-time mothers planning to exclusively/nearly exclusively breastfeed compared to automated general pregnancy/infant care texts (Text4Baby) after 8 weeks postpartum?
front_details.intervention_fragment: semi-automated breastfeeding support text messages (MILK)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: first-time mothers planning to exclusively/nearly exclusively breastfeed
front_details.outcome_fragment: perceived milk supply (feeling you have enough breast milk)

study.title: VR Intervention to Improve Police Safety
study.brief_description: The primary objective of this study is to demonstrate the efficacy of Floreo's police safety module (PSM) in adolescents and adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) by assessing improvement in police interaction skills as compared to a video modeling intervention.

front_details.question: Did immersive VR police-safety training improve police interaction skills (Police Interaction Assessment score) in adolescents and adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) receiving VR training compared to video-based police-safety training (video modeling) after 2 weeks (pre- to post-intervention)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: immersive VR police-safety training
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adolescents and adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) receiving VR training
front_details.outcome_fragment: police interaction skills (Police Interaction Assessment score)

study.title: Combination Treatment for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) After the World Trade Center (WTC) Attack
study.brief_description: This randomized controlled trial evaluates efficacy of combined prolonged exposure (PE) and the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) paroxetine in the treatment of survivors of the World Trade Center (WTC) attacks.

front_details.question: Did paroxetine (SSRI) plus prolonged exposure therapy improve remission (low PTSD symptoms: CAPS ≤20 and CGI-change=1) in WTC survivors with PTSD compared to placebo pill plus prolonged exposure therapy after 5 and 10 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: paroxetine (SSRI) plus prolonged exposure therapy
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: WTC survivors with PTSD
front_details.outcome_fragment: remission (low PTSD symptoms: CAPS ≤20 and CGI-change=1)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: placebo pill plus prolonged exposure therapy

study.title: Treatment of Pregnant Women With OUD
study.brief_description: The investigators are testing two models of support for pregnant women with an opioid use disorder (OUD)

front_details.question: Did onsite collaborative care with a care manager (CC) improve treatment retention (stayed in treatment with no gap >1 month) in pregnant and postpartum women with opioid use disorder (OUD) compared to remote ECHO provider telesupport (video mentorship) after delivery and 3 months postpartum?
front_details.intervention_fragment: onsite collaborative care with a care manager (CC)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: pregnant and postpartum women with opioid use disorder (OUD)
front_details.outcome_fragment: treatment retention (stayed in treatment with no gap >1 month)

study.brief_description: This randomized controlled trial evaluates efficacy of combined prolonged exposure (PE) and the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) paroxetine in the treatment of survivors of the World Trade Center (WTC) attacks.

front_details.question: Did paroxetine (an SSRI antidepressant) plus prolonged exposure therapy improve PTSD severity (Clinician-Administered PTSD Scale, CAPS score) in survivors of the World Trade Center (WTC) attacks with PTSD compared to placebo pill plus prolonged exposure therapy after 10 weeks?

front_details.question: Did immersive VR police-safety training (Floreo PSM) improve police interaction skills (change in Police Interaction Assessment score) in adolescents and adults with autism (ASD) compared to BE SAFE video modeling after about 2 weeks?

study.title: Treatment of Insomnia Secondary to Chronic Pain
study.brief_description: Several studies have shown that behavioral therapy for chronic pain can be beneficial for chronic pain and that behavioral therapy for insomnia can be beneficial for insomnia. However, seldom do chronic pain patients with insomnia receive a behavioral treatment for insomnia. The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether treatment for insomnia is helpful for pain and whether treatment for pain is helpful for insomnia. It will also assess whether a combined treatment is any more or less effective for pain or for sleep. Finally, the study will assess whether any of these treatments leads to improvements in immune function.

front_details.question: Did CBT for pain improve insomnia severity (Insomnia Severity Index score) in people with chronic pain compared to wait-list control (no treatment) after about 10 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: CBT for pain
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: people with chronic pain
front_details.outcome_fragment: insomnia severity (Insomnia Severity Index score)

study.title: Life Care Specialists (LCS) With a Focus on Patient Pain Management and Prevention of Substance Misuse
study.brief_description: The overall hypothesis of this randomized-controlled trial is that the introduction of a Life Care Specialist (LCS) as a novel member of the clinical care team will help reduce opioid utilization, decrease pain scores, and improve patient understanding of their addiction risk in the aftermath of orthopaedic trauma.

front_details.question: Did an inpatient pain coach who provides opioid education, behavioral pain management, and care coordination improve average pain (Numeric Rating Scale) in orthopaedic trauma patients receiving the pain coach plus usual care compared to standard pain care alone after 3 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: an inpatient pain coach who provides opioid education, behavioral pain management, and care coordination
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: orthopaedic trauma patients receiving the pain coach plus usual care
front_details.outcome_fragment: average pain (Numeric Rating Scale)

study.title: Treatment of Pregnant Women With OUD
study.brief_description: The investigators are testing two models of support for pregnant women with an opioid use disorder (OUD)

front_details.question: Did onsite collaborative care with a care manager (in-person clinic support) improve treatment engagement (completed baseline assessment and >2 opioid treatment visits) in pregnant and postpartum women with opioid use disorder compared to remote video-based provider mentorship (tele-education for clinicians) after 30 days?
front_details.intervention_fragment: onsite collaborative care with a care manager (in-person clinic support)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: pregnant and postpartum women with opioid use disorder
front_details.outcome_fragment: treatment engagement (completed baseline assessment and >2 opioid treatment visits)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: remote video-based provider mentorship (tele-education for clinicians)

study.title: Impact of Family History and Decision Support on High-risk Cancer Screening
study.brief_description: Family health history can help identify patients at higher than average risk for disease. There is no standardized system for collecting and updating family health history, using this information to determine a patient's disease risk level, and providing screening recommendations to patients and providers. Patients will enter their family health history into MeTree, a family history software program. The program will produce screening recommendations tailored to the patient's family health history. The investigators will examine whether this process increases physician referrals for, and patient uptake of, guideline-recommended screening for colorectal cancer.

front_details.question: Did entering family health history into MeTree with patient and provider decision support improve risk-appropriate colorectal cancer screening referral in patients who completed MeTree at enrollment compared to patients in the delayed (wait-list) group after 12 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: entering family health history into MeTree with patient and provider decision support
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: patients who completed MeTree at enrollment
front_details.outcome_fragment: risk-appropriate colorectal cancer screening referral

study.title: Integrated Treatment for Adolescents With ADHD
study.brief_description:
Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) exists in 20-50% of the 3 million adolescents annually enrolled in outpatient mental health and substance use treatment. Adolescents with ADHD present deficits in attention, self-regulation, and social competence that significantly impede achievement of developmental and educational milestones. Currently there are only two evidence-based treatment options for this age group: academic training and stimulant medications. Both options remain vastly underutilized. Academic training is not available in most school settings and rarely implemented in clinical care. Similarly, ADHD medications are rarely utilized with adolescents in primary or specialty care for a host of reasons related to stigma, misinformation about effects and side effects, and adolescent autonomy issues. Moreover, the widespread fragmentation of pharmacological versus behavioral services prevents families from making informed treatment selections.

The primary objective of this randomized parametric trial is to compare the effectiveness of behavioral only versus integrated (behavioral plus medication decision-making) interventions for adolescents with ADHD in outpatient behavioral services. The behavioral intervention, Changing Academic Support in the Home for Adolescents with ADHD (CASH-AA), contains three components: ADHD psychoeducation, family-based motivational interventions, and academic training. The medication decision-making intervention, Medication Integration Protocol (MIP), contain three components: psychoeducation about ADHD medication, family decision-making, and medication management. The study will compare the effects of two legitimate treatment options for adolescents with ADHD on service utilization, behavioral symptoms, and quality of life. It will generate new evidence on patient-centered treatment selection that aligns with family-specific principles and treatment goals.

This parametric comparative trial will randomly assign 140 inner-city adolescents with ADHD to (1) CASH-AA Only or (2) CASH-AA + MIP. Treatment will occur in community behavioral health clinics. All participants will receive behavioral interventions (CASH-AA): family psychoeducation in ADHD symptoms, executive functioning, and developmental impacts; family-based motivation and ADHD accommodation interventions; and academic training focused on home environment support and organizational skills. Half of the participants will also receive medication decision-making interventions (MIP): ADHD medication psychoeducation, family decision-making interventions, and (for those who elect to start medication) coordinated medication management. Half of the sample will have comorbid substance use problems. Treatment will occur in three community clinics; therapists will be randomly assigned to study condition. Caregivers and adolescents will complete assessments at baseline, 3, 6, and 12-month follow-up. Multilevel modeling will compare the effectiveness of each condition on key patient and service use outcomes. Patient-centered analyses will explore differential treatment effects based on (a) Medication decision (yes/no); (b) Substance use comorbidity (yes/no); (c) Race/Ethnicity (Hispanic, African American).

Quantitative outcome analyses will test for service use effects, symptom reduction, and quality of life improvements that are primary reasons for seeking clinical services. Qualitative interviews will document family-specific rationale for decisions about medication, compliance with behavioral and medication interventions, and suggestions for improving services and service integration. Note that families assigned to CASH-AA Only will retain the option of pursuing ADHD medication through treatment-as-usual procedures at their respective clinic. Similarly, families assigned to CASH-AA + MIP will not be required to start ADHD medication. Instead, they will receive informed-choice interventions and can choose when and if to start medication; the study will assess the impact of these decisions on clinical outcomes.

If proven efficacious, the CASH-AA and MIP protocols could be rapidly disseminated individually or as an integrated protocol into routine behavioral healthcare settings. The protocols can also be readily combined with other behavioral treatments to form a multicomponent treatment package for adolescents with co-occurring behavior problems. In addition, the family-based, patient-centered CASH-AA and MIP protocols could be delivered in conjunction with other family-based treatments or with individual approaches that flexibly include caregivers in multiple treatment sessions. This makes CASH-AA and MIP highly efficient clinical resources for addressing ADHD-related problems in any outpatient setting that serves adolescents and their families.

front_details.question: Did family- and home-based behavioral support for ADHD (CASH‑AA) improve ADHD symptoms and related problems (delinquency, substance use, internalizing/externalizing symptoms) in adolescents with ADHD receiving behavioral-only treatment compared to adolescents receiving the behavioral program plus medication decision-making (MIP) after one year?
front_details.intervention_fragment: family- and home-based behavioral support for ADHD (CASH‑AA)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adolescents with ADHD receiving behavioral-only treatment
front_details.outcome_fragment: ADHD symptoms and related problems (delinquency, substance use, internalizing/externalizing symptoms)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: adolescents receiving the behavioral program plus medication decision-making (MIP)

study.title: VR Intervention to Improve Police Safety
study.brief_description: The primary objective of this study is to demonstrate the efficacy of Floreo's police safety module (PSM) in adolescents and adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) by assessing improvement in police interaction skills as compared to a video modeling intervention.

front_details.question: Did remote at-home immersive VR police safety training (Floreo PSM) improve police interaction skills (change in Police Interaction Assessment score) in adolescents and adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) compared to treatment-as-usual (no intervention) after about 2 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: remote at-home immersive VR police safety training (Floreo PSM)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adolescents and adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD)

study.title: Telephone-Based Program to Promote Inhaled Corticosteroid Adherence Among Individuals With Asthma
study.brief_description: Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are often prescribed as a treatment for asthma. However, many individuals who take these medications do not adhere to their prescribed treatment regimen. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a telephone-based program at improving medication adherence among individuals with asthma.

front_details.question: Did automated phone refill reminders improve inhaled corticosteroid adherence (modified medication possession ratio, mMPR) in people with asthma compared to usual care after 19 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: automated phone refill reminders
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: people with asthma
front_details.outcome_fragment: inhaled corticosteroid adherence (modified medication possession ratio, mMPR)

study.title: Computerized PAINRelieveIt Protocol for Cancer Pain Control in Hospice
study.brief_description: The study purpose is to compare usual hospice care and PAINRelieveIt groups for effects on: (1) patient outcomes (analgesic adherence; worst pain intensity, satisfaction, and misconceptions) and lay caregiver outcome (pain misconceptions) in a diverse sample of 250 cancer patient-caregiver dyads receiving hospice care; and (2) nurse outcomes (obtained appropriate analgesics for patient) in a sample of hospice nurses. The investigators hypothesize that at posttest, controlling for pretest data and compared to the usual care group, the PAINRelieveIt group will: a) report decreased scores for worst pain intensity and pain misconceptions; b) have increased analgesic adherence (primary outcome); and c) have a larger proportion who report satisfaction with pain intensity and whose nurses obtained appropriate analgesics for the patients' pain.

front_details.question: Did tablet-based pain reporting with nurse decision support and tailored multimedia education improve analgesic adherence (percent of prescribed pain medicines taken) in home hospice cancer patients compared to usual hospice care (PAINReportIt summary only) after 1 week (days 1–7)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: tablet-based pain reporting with nurse decision support and tailored multimedia education
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: home hospice cancer patients
front_details.outcome_fragment: analgesic adherence (percent of prescribed pain medicines taken)

This makes CASH-AA and MIP highly efficient clinical resources for addressing ADHD-related problems in any outpatient setting that serves adolescents and their families.

front_details.question: Did family- and home-based behavioral support for ADHD (CASH‑AA) improve treatment attendance (number of therapy and medication sessions attended) in adolescents with ADHD in the behavioral-only group compared to adolescents with ADHD receiving the same behavioral program plus medication decision-making and coordinated medication management (MIP) after one year?
front_details.intervention_fragment: family- and home-based behavioral support for ADHD (CASH‑AA)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adolescents with ADHD in the behavioral-only group
front_details.outcome_fragment: treatment attendance (number of therapy and medication sessions attended)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: adolescents with ADHD receiving the same behavioral program plus medication decision-making and coordinated medication management (MIP)

study.title: Treatment of Insomnia Secondary to Chronic Pain
study.brief_description: Several studies have shown that behavioral therapy for chronic pain can be beneficial for chronic pain and that behavioral therapy for insomnia can be beneficial for insomnia. However, seldom do chronic pain patients with insomnia receive a behavioral treatment for insomnia. The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether treatment for insomnia is helpful for pain and whether treatment for pain is helpful for insomnia. It will also assess whether a combined treatment is any more or less effective for pain or for sleep. Finally, the study will assess whether any of these treatments leads to improvements in immune function.

front_details.question: Did 10 sessions of cognitive-behavioral therapy for sleep and pain improve pain severity (Multidimensional Pain Inventory pain severity subscale; lower = less pain) in patients with chronic pain and insomnia compared to wait-list control (no treatment) after about 10 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: 10 sessions of cognitive-behavioral therapy for sleep and pain
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: patients with chronic pain and insomnia
front_details.outcome_fragment: pain severity (Multidimensional Pain Inventory pain severity subscale; lower = less pain)

front_details.question: Did caregivers receiving psychoeducation and relaxation (fPER) improve patient quality of life (FACT-BMT) in allogeneic HSCT patients compared to patients whose caregivers got treatment as usual (TAU) after 6 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: caregivers receiving psychoeducation and relaxation (fPER)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: allogeneic HSCT patients
front_details.outcome_fragment: patient quality of life (FACT-BMT)

front_details.question: Did paroxetine (an SSRI) plus prolonged exposure therapy improve remission (minimal PTSD symptoms; CAPS ≤20 and CGI change=1) in WTC survivors with PTSD compared to placebo plus prolonged exposure therapy after 5 and 10 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: paroxetine (an SSRI) plus prolonged exposure therapy
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: WTC survivors with PTSD
front_details.outcome_fragment: remission (minimal PTSD symptoms; CAPS ≤20 and CGI change=1)

study.title: Treatment of Insomnia Secondary to Chronic Pain
study.brief_description: Several studies have shown that behavioral therapy for chronic pain can be beneficial for chronic pain and that behavioral therapy for insomnia can be beneficial for insomnia. However, seldom do chronic pain patients with insomnia receive a behavioral treatment for insomnia. The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether treatment for insomnia is helpful for pain and whether treatment for pain is helpful for insomnia. It will also assess whether a combined treatment is any more or less effective for pain or for sleep. Finally, the study will assess whether any of these treatments leads to improvements in immune function.

front_details.question: Did CBT for insomnia (CBT‑I; sleep-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, 10 sessions) improve blood inflammation (interleukin-6, IL-6 levels) in people with chronic pain compared to wait-list control (no treatment) after pre- to post-treatment (~10 weeks)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: CBT for insomnia (CBT‑I; sleep-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, 10 sessions)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: people with chronic pain
front_details.outcome_fragment: blood inflammation (interleukin-6, IL-6 levels)

study.title: Impact of an Atrial Fibrillation Decision Support Tool (AFDST) on Thromboprophylaxis for Atrial Fibrillation
study.brief_description: Study objective was to improve decision-making and thromboprophylaxis for patients with Atrial Fibrillation (AF) by developing and implementing a computerized decision support tool for individual patient-level decision-making about oral anticoagulant therapy. To accomplish these goals, the investigators studied the incremental impact of adding a quality-improvement (QI) intervention to an educational package (for practice staff and clinicians) using a computerized aid, the Atrial Fibrillation Decision Support Tool (AFDST) for individual patient-level decision-making about oral anticoagulant therapy in patients with non-valvular AF. The decision support tool incorporates individual patients' risk factor profiles for ischemic stroke and bleeding and provides a recommendation for treatment based upon the projected quality-adjusted life expectancy gained or lost with the addition of either oral anticoagulant therapy or aspirin compared with no thromboprophylaxis.

front_details.question: Did using an atrial fibrillation (AF) decision-support tool to recommend blood-thinning treatment improve discordant antithrombotic therapy (patients on treatment that disagreed with the tool's recommendation) in adults with non-valvular AF whose doctors got decision support plus education compared to adults with non-valvular AF whose doctors got education only after one year?
front_details.intervention_fragment: using an atrial fibrillation (AF) decision-support tool to recommend blood-thinning treatment
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adults with non-valvular AF whose doctors got decision support plus education
front_details.outcome_fragment: discordant antithrombotic therapy (patients on treatment that disagreed with the tool's recommendation)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: adults with non-valvular AF whose doctors got education only

study.title: Treatment of Pregnant Women With OUD
study.brief_description: The investigators are testing two models of support for pregnant women with an opioid use disorder (OUD)

front_details.question: Did onsite collaborative care with a care manager (onsite training and support for clinicians) improve patient activation (healthcare knowledge, skills & confidence; Patient Activation Measure, PAM) in pregnant and postpartum women with opioid use disorder (opioid addiction) compared to remote ECHO video mentorship for clinicians (tele-support and training) after baseline, 26 and 36 weeks' gestation and 3 months postpartum?
front_details.intervention_fragment: onsite collaborative care with a care manager (onsite training and support for clinicians)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: pregnant and postpartum women with opioid use disorder (opioid addiction)
front_details.outcome_fragment: patient activation (healthcare knowledge, skills & confidence; Patient Activation Measure, PAM)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: remote ECHO video mentorship for clinicians (tele-support and training)
front_details.timeframe_fragment: baseline, 26 and 36 weeks' gestation and 3 months postpartum

study.title: Treatment of Insomnia Secondary to Chronic Pain
study.brief_description: Several studies have shown that behavioral therapy for chronic pain can be beneficial for chronic pain and that behavioral therapy for insomnia can be beneficial for insomnia. However, seldom do chronic pain patients with insomnia receive a behavioral treatment for insomnia. The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether treatment for insomnia is helpful for pain and whether treatment for pain is helpful for insomnia. It will also assess whether a combined treatment is any more or less effective for pain or for sleep. Finally, the study will assess whether any of these treatments leads to improvements in immune function.

front_details.question: Did CBT for insomnia (10 sessions teaching sleep skills and relaxation) improve pain severity (Multidimensional Pain Inventory pain severity score) in patients with chronic pain compared to wait-list control (no treatment) after about 10 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: CBT for insomnia (10 sessions teaching sleep skills and relaxation)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: patients with chronic pain
front_details.outcome_fragment: pain severity (Multidimensional Pain Inventory pain severity score)

study.title: Integrated Treatment for Adolescents With ADHD
study.brief_description:
Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) exists in 20-50% of the 3 million adolescents annually enrolled in outpatient mental health and substance use treatment. Adolescents with ADHD present deficits in attention, self-regulation, and social competence that significantly impede achievement of developmental and educational milestones. Currently there are only two evidence-based treatment options for this age group: academic training and stimulant medications. Both options remain vastly underutilized. Academic training is not available in most school settings and rarely implemented in clinical care. Similarly, ADHD medications are rarely utilized with adolescents in primary or specialty care for a host of reasons related to stigma, misinformation about effects and side effects, and adolescent autonomy issues. Moreover, the widespread fragmentation of pharmacological versus behavioral services prevents families from making informed treatment selections.

The primary objective of this randomized parametric trial is to compare the effectiveness of behavioral only versus integrated (behavioral plus medication decision-making) interventions for adolescents with ADHD in outpatient behavioral services. The behavioral intervention, Changing Academic Support in the Home for Adolescents with ADHD (CASH-AA), contains three components: ADHD psychoeducation, family-based motivational interventions, and academic training. The medication decision-making intervention, Medication Integration Protocol (MIP), contain three components: psychoeducation about ADHD medication, family decision-making, and medication management. The study will compare the effects of two legitimate treatment options for adolescents with ADHD on service utilization, behavioral symptoms, and quality of life. It will generate new evidence on patient-centered treatment selection that aligns with family-specific principles and treatment goals.

This parametric comparative trial will randomly assign 140 inner-city adolescents with ADHD to (1) CASH-AA Only or (2) CASH-AA + MIP. Treatment will occur in community behavioral health clinics. All participants will receive behavioral interventions (CASH-AA): family psychoeducation in ADHD symptoms, executive functioning, and developmental impacts; family-based motivation and ADHD accommodation interventions; and academic training focused on home environment support and organizational skills. Half of the participants will also receive medication decision-making interventions (MIP): ADHD medication psychoeducation, family decision-making interventions, and (for those who elect to start medication) coordinated medication management. Half of the sample will have comorbid substance use problems. Treatment will occur in three community clinics; therapists will be randomly assigned to study condition. Caregivers and adolescents will complete assessments at baseline, 3, 6, and 12-month follow-up. Multilevel modeling will compare the effectiveness of each condition on key patient and service use outcomes. Patient-centered analyses will explore differential treatment effects based on (a) Medication decision (yes/no); (b) Substance use comorbidity (yes/no); (c) Race/Ethnicity (Hispanic, African American).

Quantitative outcome analyses will test for service use effects, symptom reduction, and quality of life improvements that are primary reasons for seeking clinical services. Qualitative interviews will document family-specific rationale for decisions about medication, compliance with behavioral and medication interventions, and suggestions for improving services and service integration. Note that families assigned to CASH-AA Only will retain the option of pursuing ADHD medication through treatment-as-usual procedures at their respective clinic. Similarly, families assigned to CASH-AA + MIP will not be required to start ADHD medication. Instead, they will receive informed-choice interventions and can choose when and if to start medication; the study will assess the impact of these decisions on clinical outcomes.

If proven efficacious, the CASH-AA and MIP protocols could be rapidly disseminated individually or as an integrated protocol into routine behavioral healthcare settings. The protocols can also be readily combined with other behavioral treatments to form a multicomponent treatment package for adolescents with co-occurring behavior problems. In addition, the family-based, patient-centered CASH-AA and MIP protocols could be delivered in conjunction with other family-based treatments or with individual approaches that flexibly include caregivers in multiple treatment sessions. This makes CASH-AA and MIP highly efficient clinical resources for addressing ADHD-related problems in any outpatient setting that serves adolescents and their families.

front_details.question: Did family- and home-based behavioral support for ADHD (CASH‑AA) improve ADHD symptoms and related problems (delinquency, substance use, internalizing and externalizing symptoms) in adolescents with ADHD receiving behavioral-only treatment compared to adolescents with ADHD receiving the behavioral program plus medication integration (MIP) after one year?
front_details.intervention_fragment: family- and home-based behavioral support for ADHD (CASH‑AA)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adolescents with ADHD receiving behavioral-only treatment
front_details.outcome_fragment: ADHD symptoms and related problems (delinquency, substance use, internalizing and externalizing symptoms)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: adolescents with ADHD receiving the behavioral program plus medication integration (MIP)

study.title: Dopamine and Insulin Resistance
study.brief_description: Obese individuals have fewer striatal dopamine type 2 receptors (DRD2) than normal weight individuals. Lower DRD2 levels are associated with addiction and a decreased sense of pleasure.Obesity is also associated with insulin resistance (poor insulin action).We propose that insulin resistance and low DRD2 are associated. Using PET imaging,we aim to determine DRD2 binding potential (BP) in the brain is associated with insulin resistance and neuroendocrine hormone levels. Obese participants will be compared to lean, gender and age similar participants. We also aim to determine the effect of caloric restriction on DRD2 BP in obese subjects

front_details.question: Did a very-low-calorie diet (VLCD; caloric restriction) improve striatal dopamine D2 receptor binding (DRD2 binding potential) in obese participants compared to their baseline before the diet after 8–10 days?
front_details.intervention_fragment: a very-low-calorie diet (VLCD; caloric restriction)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: obese participants
front_details.outcome_fragment: striatal dopamine D2 receptor binding (DRD2 binding potential)

study.title: VR Intervention to Improve Police Safety
study.brief_description: The primary objective of this study is to demonstrate the efficacy of Floreo's police safety module (PSM) in adolescents and adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) by assessing improvement in police interaction skills as compared to a video modeling intervention.

front_details.question: Did three remote at-home VR sessions (Floreo Police Safety Module) improve police interaction skills (Police Interaction Assessment score) in adolescents and adults with autism (ASD) given the VR module compared to treatment-as-usual (no VR intervention) after about 2 weeks (pre- to post-intervention)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: three remote at-home VR sessions (Floreo Police Safety Module)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adolescents and adults with autism (ASD) given the VR module
front_details.outcome_fragment: police interaction skills (Police Interaction Assessment score)

study.title: Evaluation of 3T, a Sex-Positive HIV/STI Mobile App Intervention for Young Black Men Ages 14-19 Attracted to Men
study.brief_description: This study features a 2-arm randomized controlled trial with approximately 300 young black men who have sex with men (YBMSM) to assess the effectiveness of the 3T mobile app. To be eligible participants will be required to identify as male; Black, African-American, or biracial Black/African American; age 14-19 at baseline; self-identify as gay, bisexual, fluid, or sexually attracted to men; own a smartphone, and reside in any state in the United States. Those in the treatment arm will be provided with the 3T app and those in the control group will be given access to a website with general health materials. Participants will complete brief online surveys at baseline and at 3-months following the baseline to assess effectiveness in changing sexual risk behaviors and communication and condom use behaviors and attitudes.

front_details.question: Did using a sex-positive interactive mobile app improve safer sex (less condomless anal or vaginal sex) in young Black men (age 14–19) attracted to men compared to a general health info website after 3 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: using a sex-positive interactive mobile app
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: young Black men (age 14–19) attracted to men
front_details.outcome_fragment: safer sex (less condomless anal or vaginal sex)

study.title: VR Intervention to Improve Police Safety
study.brief_description: The primary objective of this study is to demonstrate the efficacy of Floreo's police safety module (PSM) in adolescents and adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) by assessing improvement in police interaction skills as compared to a video modeling intervention.

front_details.question: Did remote at-home VR police-safety training (Floreo PSM) improve police interaction skills (Police Interaction Assessment score) in adolescents and adults with autism (ASD) compared to no intervention (treatment-as-usual, TAU) after about 2 weeks (pre- to post-intervention)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: remote at-home VR police-safety training (Floreo PSM)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adolescents and adults with autism (ASD)
front_details.outcome_fragment: police interaction skills (Police Interaction Assessment score)

study.title: Helping Empower Liver and Kidney Patients
study.brief_description: The overall purpose of this study is to develop and test a web-based decision aid (DA) to support patients with Hepatitis C and Chronic Kidney Disease during decisions about whether, when, and how to treat each illness. Patients will have the opportunity to learn about their hepatitis C and kidney disease, initiate thought about what matters most to them and choose a treatment plan for their liver and kidney disease that works best for them. Investigators will evaluate the tool's efficacy, usability, and the likelihood of using it in clinical practice. There are three (3) primary aims of this project: (1) to develop the DA; (2) to pilot-test the DA to determine efficacy, usability and likelihood of using it in routine practice; (3) to explore stakeholders feedback on the usefulness of the DA and likelihood of implementing the tool.

front_details.question: Did viewing a plain-language decision aid about hepatitis C (HCV) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) treatment options improve knowledge about HCV and CKD (percent correct on 8 questions) in people with hepatitis C (HCV) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) compared to baseline (pre-test) after viewing the decision aid (immediately, within 30 minutes)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: viewing a plain-language decision aid about hepatitis C (HCV) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) treatment options
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: people with hepatitis C (HCV) and chronic kidney disease (CKD)
front_details.outcome_fragment: knowledge about HCV and CKD (percent correct on 8 questions)
front_details.timeframe_fragment: viewing the decision aid (immediately, within 30 minutes)

However, seldom do chronic pain patients with insomnia receive a behavioral treatment for insomnia. The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether treatment for insomnia is helpful for pain and whether treatment for pain is helpful for insomnia. It will also assess whether a combined treatment is any more or less effective for pain or for sleep. Finally, the study will assess whether any of these treatments leads to improvements in immune function.

front_details.question: Did combined cognitive-behavioral therapy for sleep and pain (CBT-I/P) improve insomnia severity (Insomnia Severity Index score) in people with chronic pain and insomnia compared to wait-list control (no treatment) after about 10 weeks?

study.title: Treatment of Insomnia Secondary to Chronic Pain
study.brief_description: Several studies have shown that behavioral therapy for chronic pain can be beneficial for chronic pain and that behavioral therapy for insomnia can be beneficial for insomnia. However, seldom do chronic pain patients with insomnia receive a behavioral treatment for insomnia. The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether treatment for insomnia is helpful for pain and whether treatment for pain is helpful for insomnia. It will also assess whether a combined treatment is any more or less effective for pain or for sleep. Finally, the study will assess whether any of these treatments leads to improvements in immune function.

front_details.question: Did talk therapy to change sleep habits and thoughts (CBT-I, 10 sessions) improve insomnia severity (Insomnia Severity Index total score) in people with chronic pain and insomnia compared to wait-list control (no treatment) after about 10 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: talk therapy to change sleep habits and thoughts (CBT-I, 10 sessions)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: people with chronic pain and insomnia

study.title: Acute Exercise Effects in Obese Pregnancy
study.brief_description: Obesity before and during pregnancy is associated with a higher risk for a number of obstetric and metabolic complications in women and their offspring. Of particular importance, obese women have a higher risk of developing gestational diabetes and preeclampsia. In addition, obese women have larger offspring who have a higher risk for the development of obesity and diabetes; both largely attributed to higher maternal glycemia and glucose intolerance during pregnancy. Thus, identifying rehabilitative interventions that improve maternal and offspring metabolic and cardiovascular health in obese pregnancy are critical and have immediate and generational impact. Resistance and aerobic exercise training is a clinical staple for improving musculoskeletal, metabolic and cardiovascular health in non-gravid adolescents and adults with obesity however little is known regarding the effects of exercise during obese pregnancy. This study proposes to collect preliminary data on the independent effects of acute aerobic and resistance rehabilitative exercise on glucose metabolism and vascular function during pregnancy in n=15 obese women in order to inform a large, multisite clinical trial examining the acute and chronic effects of aerobic and resistance exercise on glucose metabolism and vascular function in normal weight, overweight and obese women during pregnancy.

front_details.question: Did 40 minutes of resistance exercise improve blood vessel function (percent change in reactive hyperemia, augmentation index) in obese women during mid-pregnancy compared to quiet rest (no exercise) after the session (immediately post-intervention, ~40 minutes)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: 40 minutes of resistance exercise
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: obese women during mid-pregnancy
front_details.outcome_fragment: blood vessel function (percent change in reactive hyperemia, augmentation index)

study.title: Do Consumer Providers Enhance Recovery?
study.brief_description: Serious mental illness (SMI) is the second most costly disorder treated in the VHA, yet clinical outcomes for these patients in public sector settings are often poor due to a combination of low quality care and severe cognitive and functional impairments evidenced by this group. While these problems are multifaceted, studies outside the VHA have shown that using "consumer providers" (CPs) can improve and augment public care. Similar to recovering addiction counselors, CPs are individuals with SMI who use their lived experiences to provide services to others with SMI. CPs can reach out to patients that are difficult to engage, assist patients with tasks of daily living, offer a variety of rehabilitation (vocational, social, residential) services, be role models and offer hope for recovery, and facilitate support groups. Randomized controlled and quasi-experimental trials, all done outside the VHA, have shown that CPs can provide services that yield at least equivalent patient outcomes with particular benefits noted on intensive case management teams. Based on these successes both the President's New Freedom Commission and the Veteran Administration's Mental Health Strategic Plan call for broader dissemination of CPs as way to make mental health services more recovery-oriented, a recent national priority. Because of these recent calls, employing mentally ill veterans has just begun, although no effort has been made to evaluate their impact inside the VA mental health system. Yet its success outside the VHA and the recent emphasis on recovery-oriented care suggests the need to test this model in the VHA.

front_details.question: Did adding a consumer provider (peer with lived mental illness) to intensive case management teams improve psychiatric symptoms (BASIS‑R score) in patients on MHICM teams with a consumer provider compared to patients on MHICM teams with care as usual after 12 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: adding a consumer provider (peer with lived mental illness) to intensive case management teams
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: patients on MHICM teams with a consumer provider
front_details.outcome_fragment: psychiatric symptoms (BASIS‑R score)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: patients on MHICM teams with care as usual

study.title: Connect-Home Clinical Trial
study.brief_description: This study will test whether transitional care targeting care needs of seriously ill, skilled nursing facility (SNF) patients and their caregivers will help to improve SNF patient outcomes (preparedness for discharge, quality of life, function and acute care use) and caregiver outcomes (preparedness for the caregiving role. caregiver burden and caregiver distress).

front_details.question: Did a two-step transitional care program (SNF planning + home-visit nurse within 24 hrs) improve preparedness for discharge (Care Transitions Measure-15 score) in seriously ill SNF patients discharged home and their caregivers compared to usual SNF discharge planning (no structured home visit) after 7 days?
front_details.intervention_fragment: a two-step transitional care program (SNF planning + home-visit nurse within 24 hrs)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: seriously ill SNF patients discharged home and their caregivers
front_details.outcome_fragment: preparedness for discharge (Care Transitions Measure-15 score)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: usual SNF discharge planning (no structured home visit)

study.title: Connect-Home Clinical Trial
study.brief_description: This study will test whether transitional care targeting care needs of seriously ill, skilled nursing facility (SNF) patients and their caregivers will help to improve SNF patient outcomes (preparedness for discharge, quality of life, function and acute care use) and caregiver outcomes (preparedness for the caregiving role. caregiver burden and caregiver distress).

front_details.question: Did a two-step transitional care program (SNF individualized transition plan + home nurse visit within 24 hours) improve caregiver readiness for caregiving (Preparedness for Caregiving Scale score) in caregivers of seriously ill SNF patients discharged to home compared to usual SNF discharge planning (no structured home visit) after 7 days?
front_details.intervention_fragment: a two-step transitional care program (SNF individualized transition plan + home nurse visit within 24 hours)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: caregivers of seriously ill SNF patients discharged to home
front_details.outcome_fragment: caregiver readiness for caregiving (Preparedness for Caregiving Scale score)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: usual SNF discharge planning (no structured home visit)
